title: Update regarding Quantum Compute
story_body:
The ongoing shortage of high-performance interconnects is wreaking havoc on the scalability of Quantum Compute's (QNTM) cutting-edge neuromorphic processing units (NPUs). As a leading provider of photonic-enabled NPUs, QNTM relies heavily on the timely delivery of low-latency, high-bandwidth interconnects to facilitate the seamless transfer of data between its proprietary quantum-inspired processing cores.

However, a perfect storm of surging demand and constrained supply has resulted in a sector-wide shortage of these critical components. The root cause of this shortage lies in the complexity of manufacturing high-speed interconnects, which necessitates the use of exotic materials and precision fabrication techniques.

The affected interconnects, which operate at speeds of up to 100 Gbps, are a crucial component in QNTM's flagship NPU, the QC-1000. This processor boasts a staggering 1 petaflop of peak performance and relies on the high-bandwidth interconnects to maintain its industry-leading benchmarks.

Industry insiders point to the constrained supply of indium phosphide (InP) substrates, a key material used in the fabrication of high-speed interconnects, as a primary contributor to the shortage. The limited availability of InP substrates has resulted in a bottleneck, hindering the production capacity of interconnect manufacturers.

The shortage has far-reaching implications for the entire NPU ecosystem, with QNTM being just one of several affected players. As the industry struggles to cope with the shortage, QNTM is exploring alternative solutions, including the development of novel interconnect architectures and the diversification of its supplier base.

While the shortage is expected to have a near-term impact on QNTM's production capacity, the company remains committed to delivering its QC-1000 NPUs to customers. As the industry works to address the shortage, QNTM is focused on mitigating the impact and ensuring the continued development of its cutting-edge NPU technology.
